title: ‘Prince of Darkness’ Tim Parker named Post Office chair
text:

Mon, Jul 13, 2015, 14:38 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 52 mins ‘Prince of Darkness’ Tim Parker named Post Office chair By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 2 hours 38 minutes ago 17.13 0.00 
Tim Parker, who has built up a reputation for his slash-and-burn approach to business, is the new chairman of the Post Office 
Tim Parker - once dubbed "the Prince of Darkness" for his willingness to swing the axe - is to become the new chairman of the Post Office, as the organisation struggles to overhaul its branch network and keep up with the times. 
Mr Parker, the current chairman of luggage firm Samsonite and the National Trust , will be charged with ensuring that the Post Office can be sustainable while also delivering on the Government's commitment to secure the future of 3,000 rural branches. 
He takes over from Alice Perkins, who announced in January she would be stepping down at the end of this month. Mr Parker will officially take up his post on 1 October. 
Mr Parker (left) was Boris Johnson's first deputy at City Hall 
Mr Parker has also been the chief executive of shoemaker Clarks, car maintenance business Kwik-Fit, and roadside recovery company The AA, as well as serving as non-executive director on the boards of Legal & General (LSE: LGEN.L - news ) , Alliance Boots and Compass Group (Other OTC: CMPGF - news ) . 
Mr Parker also had a brief spell working with Boris Johnson as the Mayor of London's first deputy. 
During his time in business he has built up a reputation for a slash-and-burn approach to organisations. He was dubbed "the Prince of Darkness" by the GMB union after turning up in his Porsche to sack a group of factory workers and halving the 7,000 workforce at the AA. * Business Profile: "Prince of Darkness" Mr Parker is also chairman of The National Trust 
“I am delighted to be taking up this appointment," said Mr Parker. 
"The Post Office provides a vital service to many people in over 11,500 locations up and down the country, and is one of Britain’s most trusted brands. I look forward to playing a role in achieving a successful and growing business whilst maintaining a clear social purpose.” 
Business minister Baroness Neville-Rolfe said: "Tim Parker brings a wealth of commercial experience and expertise, and I am delighted that he is taking up this role. 
"The Government is supporting the Post Office to modernise and become a successful commercial organisation, reducing its reliance on taxpayer subsidy. I look forward to working with Tim to continue that transformation. 
“I would also like to thank Alice Perkins for all her dedication, leadership and commitment over the last four years.”
